title: Monday Message Board
summary: John Quiggin, an Australian economist and author, has announced that he will be using Substack as a blogging platform and for his monthly email newsletter. He will continue to post on his blog as well. Quiggin also mentioned that readers can follow him on Mastodon.

title: Albanese likes fighting, but not for us
summary: Anthony Albanese, the leader of the Australian Labor Party, is criticized for his response to a question about renewable energy in Parliament. Instead of expressing willingness to work with the Parliament, Albanese attacked the Greens for pressuring him to strengthen the Housing Fund. This response is seen as evidence that Albanese will not change his approach.

title: Comment problems
summary: The article discusses a technical issue with the comment box on a WordPress website. The author acknowledges the problem and promises to investigate it, but warns that it may take some time to fix. In the meantime, the author suggests that users who are unable to have their names recorded can comment anonymously and manually add their names in the body of the comment. The author assures readers that they will regularly check and approve these comments.

title: Sandpit
summary: The article introduces a new platform called the "sandpit" for regular commenters to engage in long side discussions, conspiracy theories, and fixed ideas. It clarifies that the sandpit is not intended for visiting conspiracy theorists or trolls pretending to be such.

title: Monday Message Board
summary: John Quiggin, an Australian economist and author, has announced that he will be using Substack as a blogging platform and for his monthly email newsletter. He will continue to post on his blog as well. Quiggin also mentioned that readers can follow him on Mastodon.

title: Balance or both-sidesism
summary: The author of the article responds to a dispute with Matt Yglesias regarding the polarization of American politics. The author argues that the Republican Party has become an extreme-right party, comparable to Fidesz in Hungary, while the Democratic Party remains a moderate party of the center and center-left. The author criticizes an article by Yglesias titled "Polarization is a choice," stating that it promotes a false equivalence between the two parties. The author asserts that the polarization in American politics is primarily driven by the radicalization of the Republican Party, fueled by interactions between Republican voters and right-wing media. The author concludes that the analysis of the US political scene as a contest between two normal political parties is fundamentally flawed, and that the intention to establish a permanent right-wing dictatorship is evident in certain projects.

title: Why Are China’s Households in the Doldrums?
summary: China's household balance sheets have been damaged by a prolonged borrowing binge, COVID-19 impacts, and a slump in the property market. As a result, consumer sentiment and confidence in future income gains are at record lows. The collapse of the property market has also led to a decline in residential investment spending and a decrease in property sales. Chinese households have responded by paying down their mortgage debt and increasing their savings deposits, indicating a shift towards risk aversion. However, these actions have contributed to a decline in consumer borrowing and slowed consumer credit growth. The Chinese government's efforts to revive demand for new homes have been unsuccessful, and policymakers face the challenge of reversing households' pessimistic attitudes to boost consumption and economic growth.

title: Who Uses “Buy Now, Pay Later?”
summary: A study conducted by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York has found that "buy now, pay later" (BNPL) services are being used by a wide range of consumers, but there are concerns about the potential risks associated with these payment plans. The study found that while BNPL can expand financial inclusion, especially for those with low credit scores, it also disproportionately attracts consumers with unmet credit needs and limited credit access. These users are more financially fragile and have a higher likelihood of accumulating excessive debt. The study also highlighted that BNPL loans may not benefit unbanked consumers or those who are "credit invisible." Additionally, there are concerns that BNPL may enable consumers to spend more than they otherwise would, leading to overextension and financial stress. The study calls for more data and analysis to fully understand the risks and benefits of BNPL and its impact on consumers' financial well-being.

title: The New York Fed DSGE Model Forecast— September 2023
summary: The Federal Reserve Bank of New York has updated its economic forecasts using its dynamic stochastic general equilibrium (DSGE) model. The model predicts that the economy will remain resilient despite the tightening of monetary policy. Output growth is projected to be higher than previously forecasted, with a lower probability of a recession. Inflation projections remain close to previous forecasts, and the model expects inflation to return to the Federal Open Market Committee's (FOMC) goal by the end of next year. The forecast also shows that the output gap will be higher than previously estimated, indicating that the strength of the economy is driven by demand factors rather than supply factors. The real natural rate of interest is expected to decline over the forecast horizon. The article includes tables and charts that provide a visual representation of the forecasts. It is important to note that the DSGE model forecast is not an official forecast of the New York Fed, but rather an input to the Research staff's overall forecasting process.

title: Dublin Industry at EEC Accession
summary: The article is about an upcoming talk by the author, who will be discussing a segment of their new book at the Dublin Festival of History. The talk will focus on Dublin industry during the European Economic Community (EEC) accession, specifically the leading firms and factories. The event will take place on October 4 at Pearse Street Library and admission is free. No booking is required, and seats will be allocated on a first-come, first-served basis. More details about the event can be found on the Dublin Festival of History website.

title: Updating Polya on Style
summary: The author reflects on George Polya's book "How to Solve It" and suggests an amendment to Polya's second rule of style. Instead of saying both things at the same time, the author proposes saying the first thing and then stopping. Another colleague suggests a more cynical amendment, stating that if you have two things to say, it's better to say nothing because nobody wants to hear it.

title: #8 Lindbergh SpA
summary: The article is too lengthy to be summarized.

title: Feedback from the Lyon Pôle bourse Forum part 1: Visiativ
summary: French micro, small, and mid-cap companies are the focus of a series of articles. Visiativ, a French company, has announced a new strategic plan to achieve €500 million in sales by 2028, with 50% coming from international markets. The company's H1 2023 results showed increased expenses due to brand unification efforts. Sales teams' incentives have been changed to align with the transition to a SAAS model. Visiativ has implemented an employee shareholding plan, bringing their stake up to 6.37%. The company is pursuing external growth through resellers/integrators of Dassault Systèmes solutions, consulting, and software editing. Visiativ uses factoring to finance working capital and neutralize seasonality. They immobilize some R&D to demonstrate innovation. While Visiativ currently relies on Dassault Systèmes products for 50% of their sales, they aim to decrease this percentage over time. The author expresses hesitation in investing in Visiativ due to their dependency on an outside product. The company has started paying dividends since 2021, potentially due to financial leverage from the Alliativ holding.

title: Writer Office Hours 📅
summary: The Substack team is offering a Q&A session for writers on the platform. They will be answering questions and providing insights in the comments section for one hour. Writers are encouraged to continue the conversation even after the session ends. This is an opportunity for writers to ask questions about Substack or provide feedback on features and tools. The article also mentions that there will be a break from Office Hours next week for a monthly Shoutout Thread.

title: Grow: How Elise Loehnen moved her Instagram followers to Substack and got paid for her work
summary: Elise Loehnen, a writer with 80,000 Instagram followers, shares her insights on monetizing her audience and growing her Substack newsletter in an interview with Substack. Loehnen turned on paid subscriptions from the start and saw her Instagram followers become some of her first and highest-paying subscribers. She emphasizes the importance of writing compelling content and letting it speak for itself, rather than using clickbait or sales tactics. Loehnen also paywalls her evergreen content and regularly promotes older posts to drive paid subscriptions. She discusses her content strategy, which includes short essays, Q&As with experts, and additional content like word etymology videos and podcast episode pages. Loehnen aims to build her Substack enough to reduce her reliance on Instagram and hopes to eventually hire a full-time editor. She advises other writers to turn on paid subscriptions and focus on creating valuable content that people will forward to their friends.

title: Riassunto settimanale 01/10/2023
summary: The article discusses the recent rise in global interest rates and its impact on government bonds. Long-term government bond yields in Europe and America have reached levels not seen in over a decade, increasing the cost of financing government expenses. The article also mentions the widening spread between Italian and German bonds and the normalization of yield curves. It highlights the possibility of interest rates reaching 7% and the opening of a large position betting on Fed Funds rates exceeding 6%. The article notes the difficult month of September for global stocks, with negative returns due to rising interest rates, potential government shutdowns, worker strikes, and economic difficulties in Europe. It also mentions the changing dynamics within the Republican Party and the lack of surprises in the second debate among Republican candidates for the presidential nomination. The article concludes by discussing the rise in oil prices and the potential for a Trump vs. Biden rematch in the next election.

title: Riassunto settimanale 24/09/2023
summary: The article discusses the decision of the Federal Reserve (Fed) to not raise interest rates and the impact on the market. It highlights the focus on the Fed's statement and press conference by Powell, which provided mixed signals about the economy. The article also mentions three significant threats to the US economy: the end of the student loan moratorium, a potential federal budget closure, and strikes in the automotive sector. The bond market was heavily affected, with yields reaching their highest levels in 20 years in both Europe and the US. The article also discusses the situation in Italy, with concerns about the Italian-German spread and various stories in the stock market, including Telecom Italia, Mediobanca, and the banking sector. In terms of macroeconomic indicators, there were slight declines in the US housing market and negative trends in French GDP, while Germany showed some improvement in the services sector. The article concludes by mentioning positive export data from South Korea, which could indicate a more positive outlook for the global economy. The upcoming economic calendar includes key data releases in the US and Europe.

title: The Trouble With Charles Schwab
summary: Charles Schwab's financial position has weakened, with a 44% decline in bank deposits over the past five quarters and substantial unrealized losses on its security portfolio. Its Tangible Common Equity capital is at just 1.8% of total assets, and it likely has negative tangible equity value. The company's future depends on customer decisions, monetary policy, regulatory action, and how it navigates these challenges. Charles Schwab Bank, the company's primary bank, has seen a significant decline in deposits due to rising interest rates. The company has drawn down its cash balance, reduced its securities portfolio, increased short-term borrowings, and brokered high-cost Certificates of Deposit to manage the cash outflow. While the company has access to substantial liquidity, any further borrowing or brokered deposits would be dilutive to net interest margins and capital balances. The decline in deposits has also impaired the value of the company's assets, resulting in unrealized losses and a decline in equity capital. The company's equity measures have deteriorated, but its Common Equity Tier 1 regulatory capital remains relatively constant due to the exclusion of unrealized losses. However, new regulations may change this treatment. If the regulatory change is implemented, it will be a headwind to Schwab's earnings and balance-sheet flexibility. The company may have negative tangible equity capital on a fair-market-value basis, but its reported regulatory capital ratios and Tangible Common Equity will remain positive.

title: Higher for (a little bit) Longer
summary: The Federal Reserve's long-run estimate of 2.5% for interest rates has remained unchanged since 2020, despite aggressive rate hikes in the short-term. This static estimate may be driven by factors such as credibility concerns and a preference for tackling inflation at the front end of the yield curve. The Fed's policy of raising short-term rates while maintaining a static long-run estimate softens the impact of rate hikes and allows borrowers to lock in debt at advantageous long-term fixed rates. However, the Fed has been forced to push up its dot plot for the next several years, leading to higher long-term interest rates. The recent FOMC meeting saw the Fed removing two rate cuts from its projections for 2024, effectively raising its rate guidance for 2024 and 2025. This adjustment in guidance has put incremental pressure on the long-end of the yield curve, with the entire U.S. Treasury yield curve currently sitting at cycle highs. The rationale for this increase may be stronger GDP growth projections or a gradual shift in the Fed's opinion on the neutral rate in a post-COVID economy.

title: 🏦AI Is Turning Clouds Into Banks
summary: The upcoming executive order on AI from the White House may require cloud computing platforms to share customer information with regulators, according to a report by Semafor. This approach, similar to a "know your customer" scheme, aims to prevent bad actors and foreign adversaries from accessing AI computing power. The regulation would be applied to well-established cloud platforms such as AWS, Azure, GCP, Oracle, and IBM, which already have experience in regulatory compliance due to their work with financial institutions. Requiring cloud platforms to share customer information with regulators could also benefit AI startups by relieving them of the compliance burden. However, there are potential drawbacks to this approach, such as the difficulty of drawing a compute threshold and the possibility of regulatory capture, where incumbents benefit from increased regulation. Overall, the author believes that some level of regulation is necessary for AI, and requiring transparency from cloud platforms and treating them like banks is a reasonable approach.

title: Friday Haymaker
summary: The article discusses the current state of the American economy and the potential consequences of excessive borrowing. It highlights the challenges posed by a shrinking workforce and tax base, as well as the impending retirement wave of the baby-boom generation. The article also emphasizes the importance of fiscal responsibility and the potential negative effects of unsustainable borrowing. Additionally, the article mentions the recent weakness in agricultural stocks and suggests a slow, dollar-cost-averaging approach for investors. It provides a list of recommended investment opportunities, including farm machinery stocks, Japanese yen, gold miners, cyber security software stocks, and more. The article concludes with a spotlight on Devon Energy, a company that has experienced a significant decline in stock price due to a correction in oil prices and a bear market in natural gas. Despite the decline, the article suggests that the stock may present a buying opportunity due to its low price-to-earnings ratio.

title: Guest Making Hay Monday - September 25th, 2023
summary: The article discusses the current conditions for buying houses and the negative outlook for the homebuilders market. It highlights the low buyer traffic and affordability levels, which are at their worst since the 1980s. The article also mentions the performance of the leading homebuilder ETF, which is down 8% this month but still up 26% for the year. The article then shifts focus to emerging market debt and the reluctance of U.S. investors to buy it. It points out that many developing nations have better fiscal and monetary policies than the U.S. and have amassed trillions of dollars in foreign currency reserves. The article concludes by discussing Neil Howe's book, "The Fourth Turning Is Here," which suggests that the U.S. is on the cusp of a radical political makeover. It introduces the No Labels movement as a potential solution to the current political divide and calls for a rational and viable alternative to the current system. The article also includes a guest article by Michael Lewitt, who discusses the negative consequences of the policy responses to major events over the past 20 years and the need for a crisis to force a change in the system.

title: Friday Haymaker
summary: The article discusses the potential investment opportunity in the Japanese yen. The author believes that the yen is undervalued and presents a long-term investment opportunity. They mention that the Bank of Japan's yield curve control policy, which artificially suppresses interest rates, may be coming to an end, which could lead to a rally in the yen. However, despite this potential catalyst, the yen has not experienced a significant price surge. The article includes charts showing the exchange rate between the yen and the dollar over the past decade. The author acknowledges that there may be a drag or friction cost when holding yen positions due to the wide spread between US T-bill rates and short rates in Japan. Overall, the author remains optimistic about the yen as a long-term investment.

title: Dividend Cuts: The Ultimate Guide
summary: NorthWest Healthcare Properties REIT has cut its dividend by over 50%, from $0.067 per month to $0.03. The company had a lot of variable rate debt and borrowed aggressively to buy assets, which has now come back to bite them. The article discusses strategies to identify potential dividend cuts before they become obvious, such as avoiding chasing high yields and focusing on stocks with low payout ratios. The author also suggests analyzing the situation and earnings of high yield stocks, as well as considering any recent changes that may affect the company's ability to maintain its dividend. The article concludes by discussing how to deal with a dividend cut, including the option of selling immediately or waiting for a potential rebound. Ultimately, the author recommends diversifying the portfolio with stocks that have strong cash flow, solid moats, and good management to minimize the risk of dividend cuts.

title: Labrador Iron Ore: A Sustainable 11% Yield... Sort of
summary: The article discusses Labrador Iron Ore, a company that operates iron ore mines in Canada. The company has a sustainable dividend yield of 11% and has been able to maintain its dividend payments even during economic downturns. Labrador Iron Ore has a strong balance sheet and generates significant cash flow, which allows it to continue paying dividends to its shareholders. The company's operations are located in Labrador and Quebec, which are known for their high-quality iron ore deposits. Labrador Iron Ore has long-term contracts with major steel producers, ensuring a stable demand for its products. The company also benefits from low production costs and a favorable exchange rate, which contribute to its profitability. Overall, Labrador Iron Ore is a reliable investment option for dividend investors looking for sustainable returns.

title: Premium Brands: Got Meat?
summary: The article discusses Premium Brands Holdings Corporation, a Canadian food processing company, and its recent acquisition of a majority stake in Got Meat, a specialty meat distributor. The acquisition is part of Premium Brands' strategy to expand its presence in the specialty meat market and diversify its product offerings. Got Meat is known for its high-quality, ethically sourced meat products, which aligns with Premium Brands' focus on premium and sustainable food options. The article highlights the potential benefits of the acquisition, including increased market share and access to new distribution channels. It also mentions the positive impact on Premium Brands' financial performance, with the company reporting strong revenue growth in recent years. Overall, the acquisition of Got Meat is seen as a strategic move that will further strengthen Premium Brands' position in the food processing industry.

title: Why I Don't Care About Beating The Market
summary: The article discusses the concept of beating the market in investing. The author argues that while beating the market may be important for professional investors, it is not as crucial for amateur investors. The author also explores the challenge of determining which market index to compare one's portfolio performance to. They explain that their portfolio consists of Canadian stocks with a small number of US equities, making it difficult to find a suitable benchmark. The author emphasizes that their financial goals have shifted from chasing total returns to focusing on cash flow and dividends. They believe that even if they underperform the market slightly, they can still achieve wealth and financial security. The article concludes by stating that the purpose of investing is to become wealthy, not necessarily to beat an index, and that active investing should be about reaching one's financial goals rather than outperforming a benchmark.

title: Sleep Country: A Debate on Moats
summary: The article discusses Sleep Country, a Canadian mattress retailer, and the debate surrounding its competitive advantage or "moat." The author examines various factors that contribute to Sleep Country's moat, including its strong brand recognition, extensive store network, and exclusive partnerships with major mattress manufacturers. The article also highlights potential threats to Sleep Country's moat, such as increasing competition from online retailers and changing consumer preferences. The author concludes that while Sleep Country's moat may not be impenetrable, the company's strong market position and strategic initiatives make it a compelling investment opportunity for dividend investors.

title: Thrown for a LOOP
summary: The Law of One Price, Discounted Cash Flow analysis, and Covered Interest Rate Parity are concepts that ensure pricing consistency in financial markets. However, these concepts are showing evidence of breaking down due to increasing regulatory rigidity and reliance on systematic portfolio construction approaches. The death of the 60/40 equity/bond portfolio is also being questioned, as few investors actually hold portfolios that adhere to this allocation. The trend towards passive investment and systematic portfolio rebalancing is contributing to market inefficiency, as fixed weight rebalancing strategies lack a self-correcting mechanism. While it is uncertain when a correction in mispricing will occur, it is likely to be qualitative rather than quantitative. The current bond/equity mispricing resembles the persistent undervaluation of value stocks, and there is a fear that it may persist longer than anticipated.

title: Please Don't Squeeze the High Yield
summary: Simplify will be hosting their third annual Entering The Fall (ETF) conference on September 26th, featuring fireside chats with Boaz Weinstein, Danielle DiMartino Booth, Jonathan Ward, John O'Connor, and Perth Tolle. The event will benefit Coney Island Prep, a public charter school in New York City. The article discusses the historical trend of declining real interest rates and argues that recent increases in interest rates are temporary and driven by central bank policies rather than inflationary pressures. It highlights the growing risk of refinancing, particularly in the high-yield sector, and warns of potential financial vulnerability if interest rates remain high. The author also discusses the long-term trend of lower real interest rates and attributes it to factors such as population pressures and surplus resources. The article concludes by noting that the current rise in interest rates is due to central bank actions and emphasizes the unprecedented speed and magnitude of this interest rate hiking cycle.

title: Links For September 2023
summary:

title: Book Review: Beelzebub's Tales To His Grandson
summary: The article discusses a book review of "Beelzebub's Tales to His Grandson" by G.I. Gurdjieff. The book is described as a complex and esoteric work that explores various philosophical and spiritual concepts. The author of the review highlights the difficulty of understanding the book and the need for patience and perseverance to fully grasp its teachings. The review also mentions the unique writing style of Gurdjieff, which includes long, meandering sentences and unconventional grammar. Despite its challenging nature, the book is praised for its depth and thought-provoking ideas. The review concludes by recommending the book to those interested in delving into esoteric philosophy and willing to put in the effort to understand its complex concepts.

title: Open Thread 295
summary: The weekly visible open thread on the ACX blog is open for discussion. The author mentions the recent Manifest conference and plans to write about it soon. Brandon Hendrickson, the winner of a recent contest, has responded to comments on his review and is looking for help with his project of creating Egan-inspired schools. The author also highlights two interesting comments from the week: one about SpaceX's performance compared to other aerospace contractors and another about Elon Musk's mental health issues and chronic pain.

The study found that while BNPL can expand financial inclusion, especially for those with low credit scores, it also disproportionately attracts consumers with unmet credit needs and greater financial fragility. title: Deep Dive: Zebra Technologies (ZBRA)
summary: Zebra Technologies, a high-quality industrial company, is currently experiencing a downturn due to disappointing Q2 numbers and reduced full-year guidance. The decline is attributed to the normalization of pandemic-level demand, particularly in the retail and logistics sectors. Additionally, Zebra faced a significant litigation settlement payment to competitor Honeywell, impacting its net income. However, despite these challenges, Zebra's growth potential is not reflected in its current valuation. With America's manufacturing construction activity at historically high levels, driven by onshoring and government stimulus, it is expected that spending will eventually lead to supply chain investments and new equipment purchases. Furthermore, Zebra's strategic shift from a hardware-centric company to a solutions provider offers ample growth opportunities, particularly in labor optimization solutions. The company has a capable management team with a track record of driving growth organically and through acquisitions. Overall, patient investors may find Zebra Technologies to be an attractive opportunity, considering its business, management, growth prospects, challenges, potential disruptions, and valuation.

title: 450: Apple's iPhone Pricing, Hyperscalers, Google, Capital-Light Businesses, Rory Sutherland, Norway, Spotify AI, and Hitchcock
summary: The article discusses the idea that nobody truly knows how others raise their children. The author points out that our understanding of parenting is limited by various factors, such as our own childhood memories being filtered through a child's perspective and the modification of memories over time. Observing parents in public spaces also presents a distorted view due to the observer effect and the lack of context. The author emphasizes that even experts in the field of parenting do not have a representative view, as their observations are based on a biased sample. The article concludes by highlighting the importance of recognizing the limitations of our knowledge about parenting.

title: 449: Amazon + Anthropic, TSMC AZ, Costco, Xero Shoes, Microsoft + Activision, Bloomberg for Sale, AI Copyright, and The Bear
summary: Amazon is set to invest up to $4 billion in AI lab Anthropic, making it their major partner. Anthropic will use AWS as their primary cloud provider and utilize AWS' Trainium and Inferentia chips for model training and inference. The investment also includes provisions for using GCP for some of their compute. In addition, Arizona is trying to persuade TSMC to add advanced-packaging capabilities to their fabs in the state.

title: Friday Kibbitz: What is your favorite rainy day recipe?
summary: The article discusses the concept of "kibbitz" and its significance in Jewish culture. Kibbitz refers to the act of socializing, chatting, and exchanging stories and opinions. It is seen as a way to connect with others and build community. The author explores the different ways in which kibbitz can be experienced, such as through family gatherings, synagogue events, or even online platforms. The article also highlights the importance of kibbitz in preserving Jewish traditions and passing them down to future generations. Overall, the article emphasizes the value of kibbitz as a means of fostering connection, sharing knowledge, and strengthening Jewish identity.

title: Vegetable Stew for Couscous
summary: The article discusses the author's love for seeking out Jewish communities and tables when traveling. The author shares a story about a Shabbat dinner in Rome that inspired their passion for Jewish cuisine. They also describe their experiences dining with Roman Jewish families and enjoying traditional meals. The article includes photos of the meals and highlights the unique blend of newness and familiarity that these encounters provide. The author concludes by sharing a recipe for Vegetable Stew for Couscous, which is perfect for Sukkot. The stew is warm, comforting, and filled with fall vegetables and spices. The author encourages readers to seek out Jewish communities and tables when they travel and asks them to share their own experiences in the comments.

title: Albanese is setting back the cause of indigenous Australians
summary: The article discusses the ongoing campaign for the "Voice" referendum in Australia, which has become a divisive issue. The referendum, set for October 14th, requires a majority of Australian voters in a majority of states to pass. Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has tied his fate to the outcome, with a win bolstering his status within the party and a loss potentially leading to his slide into illegitimacy. The author argues that Albanese made a mistake by holding the referendum separately from elections, as legislating for "The Voice" during Labor's "honeymoon" period would have attracted less controversy. The campaign has driven a wedge between Australians and created an environment of anger, hate, and abuse. The author also raises concerns about the potential consequences of enshrining race into the constitution, citing Malaysia as an example where such policies led to a neo-feudal society and institutionalized corruption. The article concludes by suggesting that there could be a better way to address the issues faced by indigenous Australians.

title: Guest Editorial: PM Anwar Gives Agong ‘Green Light’ On Pardon For Najib
summary: Former Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak, who is currently serving a jail sentence, may be granted a pardon in the future. There is speculation that the pardon could be granted sooner rather than later, in order to allow voters to forget about Najib's conviction before the next election. The power to grant a pardon lies with the Agong, the Malaysian monarch, who can act on it with or without the advice of the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister, Anwar Ibrahim, has reportedly given his "green light" for the pardon. There are arguments in favor of a pardon for Najib, including the belief that he was not given the benefit of the doubt during his trial and that there may have been a miscarriage of justice. However, there are also those who oppose a pardon for Najib, including the media and the Bar Council, who have engaged in a "Trial by Media" against him. The decision to grant a pardon ultimately rests with the Agong, and there is no legal recourse against his decision.

title: Teacher Absenteeism has profound effects upon students
summary: Teacher absenteeism in government schools in Malaysia is a significant issue that negatively impacts students. A recent court case in Kota Kinabalu highlighted the problem, with a teacher being absent from class for seven months. The extent of the issue is difficult to measure due to deliberate cover-ups, falsification of records, and a culture of fear that prevents students from reporting absenteeism. Teacher absenteeism affects students' ability to progress in their education and perform well in exams, keeping them trapped in low-income social strata. It also hinders their ability to learn English, which is a compulsory subject for university admission. Teacher absenteeism can lead to mental health issues, loss of trust in adults, and a loss of hope for the future. It also degrades the quality of the workforce in the coming generation. The problem is a symptom of dissatisfaction within the teaching profession, with low motivation levels and some teachers engaging in other income-earning activities during school hours. The issue needs to be addressed before any other education reforms can be effective.

title: Lawyers who use defamation laws as weapons for their clients
summary: Defamation laws in Malaysia are being weaponized by lawyers to silence critics and prevent open public discussion. Lawyers are using these laws to intimidate writers, journalists, activists, and news portals critical of their clients. Some lawyers are even acting as proxies to cover up corruption by politicians. In addition to using defamation laws, lawyers are also attempting to extort cash payments from those accused of defaming their clients. They are making frivolous claims against legitimate criticisms and using defamation as a means to censor people. The article provides a list of lawyers who are questionable in their ethics and moral compass when it comes to using defamation laws. The author encourages readers to add names of lawyers who are abusing these laws in the comments. The article concludes by stating that lawyers have become the biggest obstacle to uncovering corruption in Malaysia.

title: PDF Book: Opportunity, Strategy and Entrepreneurship, Vol. 2
summary: This article discusses a book that aims to bring the concept of opportunity into mainstream discussion and consideration in the field of business. The book presents a meta-theory that dissects all the elements of opportunity to better understand this phenomenon. The first volume of the book explores the nature of opportunity and its close link to society's development. It also discusses how our attitudes, biases, and mental maps influence how we perceive opportunity. The book emphasizes the importance of creativity and the ability to make connections in recognizing opportunities. The author argues that opportunity should be the driver of strategy and entrepreneurship, rather than focusing solely on the firm and its strengths and weaknesses. The book takes a unique approach to strategy formation and entrepreneurship development, considering variables and factors influenced by psychological, economic, and social dynamics. Overall, the book offers a comprehensive exploration of opportunity from various perspectives and encourages readers to rethink their approach to business and seize opportunities.

title: Something is rotten at Kledang Saiong Forest Reserve
summary: The Kledong Saiong Forest Reserve in Perak, Malaysia is facing environmental destruction as the state government awards logging and plantation concessions to corporations. Sahabat Alam Malaysia (SAM), an NGO, is actively opposing the plan to log and replace the natural forest with fast-growing plantation crops. The area is home to endangered species such as the Helmeted Hornbill and the Asian Brown Tortoise. The proposed logging site is located near an Orang Asli Kampong, and disturbing the natural habitat could lead to dangerous human-wildlife contact. Four companies have been given land within the forest reserve, all sharing the same registered address and appearing to be owned by the same group of shareholders. The Perak State government has not considered the interests of the Orang Asli living in the forest reserve. This case adds to the reputation of the Perak State government as an environmental vandal, as they have also allowed the destruction of the Dhamma Sakyamuni Caves Monastery.

title: The renaming of Jalan Wong Ah Jang in Kuantan is another link to Malaysia’s heritage lost
summary: The Kuantan City Council in Malaysia has decided to rename Jalan Wong Ah Jang 1 to 5 to Jalan Bunga Kamboja 1 to 5, which is seen as part of a trend of eliminating Malaysia's heritage and sense of history. Wong Ah Jang, who arrived in Kuantan at the age of 15, played a significant role in the town's community development in the 1920s. This renaming is not an isolated incident, as several roads in Malaysia have had their names changed in the past, erasing the historical connections and heritage of the cities. The article argues that these name changes have taken away from the public's view of the history and the people involved in the formation and development of these cities. The younger generation is now without visual links to Malaysia's colonial past, which played a crucial role in building the nation.

title: Ops Hadir: Malaysia in conjunction with the CIA run operations in the South China Sea
summary: The Research Division of the Prime Minister's Department in Malaysia, also known as the Malaysian External Intelligence Organization (MEIO), is reportedly conducting joint operations with the US Central Intelligence Agency (CIA) in the South China Sea. The aim of these missions is to assist in maintaining Malaysian sovereignty in disputed sea areas and support US operations to enforce the "rules-based order" in the region. The project involves monitoring warships and fishing vessels, as well as leveraging support from parties like Petronas and the Sarawak Coast Guard to track the movements of Chinese and Vietnamese vessels. In addition, hydrological data, mineral, and seismic maps are being developed in disputed areas. The operations come at a time when Malaysia is facing increased Chinese incursions into disputed territories and rising tension between China and the United States. Malaysia is deploying more than naval forces for surveillance, including a Diamond Aircraft 42-MPP modified for surveillance. The joint operations with the US are seen as a way to protect Malaysian sovereignty and are part of the US's containment strategy against Chinese activities in the South China Sea. The program has also created leverage for Malaysia in its communications with China over the South China Sea.

title: A $1 Acquisition Could Lead This Stock To Double

The company's competent management, who have a vested interest in the business, further strengthens the bullish case for Cogent Communications.

title: Super-Spiked Videopods (EP30): Profits Over Preaching
summary: The article discusses three questions related to the energy industry. The first question addresses whether peak oil supply fears will return. The author argues that there is no peak to oil demand in the foreseeable future and that all forms of energy will be needed to meet the growing demand. The second question examines the outperformance of traditional energy stocks compared to new energy stocks and what it says about opportunities in the industry. The author suggests that the market is demanding evidence of profitable scaling in new energy business models. The third question explores whether new energies have a future. The author emphasizes that struggles in one area of new energy, such as offshore wind, do not indicate that the entire sector is doomed. They believe that both new and old forms of energy will be necessary to meet long-term energy needs. Overall, the article highlights the importance of considering different perspectives and opportunities in the energy industry.

title: Less Tax Evasion, a Profit Boom, and a Persistent Interest Puzzle: Highlights of the 2023 Comprehensive NIPA Revisions (Part 1)
summary: The U.S. national accounts measure economic activity through two aggregates: GDP (expenditure-based estimate) and GDI (income-based estimate). However, there is often a "statistical discrepancy" between the two, leading to contradictory answers about the state of the economy. Since 2021, there have been large swings in the discrepancy between GDP and GDI. The gap was initially due to GDP understating business investment and GDI overstating workers' wages. More recently, GDI has been falling sharply compared to GDP because of a 31% drop in American businesses' net interest payments. The Bureau of Economic Analysis (BEA) publishes comprehensive revisions every five years, which have resulted in both measures of economic output being revised up by nearly 2% as of 2023Q2. However, the gap between the income-based and expenditure-based estimates remains large. The revisions have been influenced by changes in the treatment of regulated investment companies, growth in corporate profits during the pandemic, new estimates of tax evasion, revisions in spending on imputed rent, and changes in investment spending. The discrepancy in net interest payments by businesses also persists.

title: Post-reorg stock at 3.7x EBITDA

The company's gross debt has decreased from $2.6 billion to $1.25 billion, interest expense has decreased from $250 million to $150 million, and liquidity has increased with $500 million in gross cash. title: Quick Value 9.26.23 ($VSTS)
summary: Aramark is set to spin off its uniform rental and workplace supplies division, Vestis Corp, at the end of September. Vestis provides uniform rentals and workplace supplies to businesses, with total sales of $2.7 billion in 2022. The uniform rental market is estimated to be worth $10.3 billion, with Cintas as the clear leader. Vestis is targeting 5-7% sales growth and 18-20% EBITDA margins by 2028. The spin-off is expected to have a loaded 4x levered balance sheet and a discount to peers due to high leverage. The estimated equity value of Vestis is $7-8.50 per share. Aramark's remaining business, focused on food and facilities management, operates in a $540 billion market. The balance sheet is 4.7x levered, and the business is seen as a levered COVID recovery play. The estimated value of Aramark's remaining business is $25-30 per share, with potential additional value from seasonal cash generation and asset sales. Both Vestis and Aramark's remaining business will start with around 4x leverage and plan to reduce it over the next few years.

title: Etsy Deep Dive
summary: Etsy, the handmade marketplace, has faced challenges in increasing buyer frequency and cross-category purchases. Despite adding almost 50 million new buyers and doubling gross merchandise sales, Etsy's stock has dropped 80% from its peak. The company's CEO, Josh Silverman, has been successful in reversing Etsy's profitability and driving growth, but has also made mistakes with acquisitions. The report explores Etsy's history, competition, management, value proposition, revenue model, and valuation. It analyzes the impact of Etsy's actions on buyer frequency and provides insights into the company's future. The report also discusses the challenges Etsy faces in balancing its mission with sound business judgment and increasing buyer engagement. Despite the recent decline in stock price, Etsy still has potential for growth and improvement.

title: The Green Trade Wars
summary: The world is experiencing exponential growth in the adoption of clean-energy technologies, particularly solar, batteries, and electric vehicles (EVs). Solar output has nearly doubled since 2019, with some countries generating over 10% of their electricity from solar. EV sales have increased from 2.2 million in 2019 to an estimated 14 million this year, and EVs could make up 1 in 5 new vehicles sold worldwide. The growth of these technologies has led to a surge in battery manufacturing, with the US and EU seeing significant increases in production. However, China remains the dominant player in solar manufacturing, accounting for a large share of global production. The US and EU are trying to catch up but still rely heavily on imports, particularly from China. Geopolitical competition for control over these industries is intensifying, leading to green trade wars and efforts to onshore manufacturing. The article highlights the importance of international cooperation and coordination to avoid underbuilding green energy technologies and to ensure a smooth transition to a clean energy future.

title: At least five interesting things for your weekend (#15)
summary: The article discusses five interesting topics. First, it highlights the improvement in working-class wealth in the US, with the bottom 50% of households experiencing strong wealth growth in real terms since 2012. Second, it explores the increasing health inequality in America, particularly among those without college degrees, as evidenced by declining life expectancies. Third, it examines the rise of zero-sum thinking in the US, as shown by a survey that indicates younger Americans have a higher index of zero-sum thinking compared to older generations. Fourth, it emphasizes the challenges of obtaining accurate economic data, citing examples of historical GDP per capita estimates and discrepancies in energy price indices. Finally, it addresses the distinction between indigenous knowledge and science, asserting that while indigenous knowledge is valuable, it is not equivalent to science in terms of transferability and testability.

title: The traditional auto industry is doomed
summary: President Biden recently made history by joining striking UAW workers near Detroit, solidifying his image as a champion of the working class. This comes as part of a larger labor revival in the US, with major strikes happening across various industries. The labor revival has the support of the Biden Administration and the American people, as unions are more popular than they have been in decades. However, the UAW strike may face challenges due to the ongoing shift from internal combustion cars to electric vehicles in the auto industry. This shift will reduce the importance of traditional heavily unionized industry clusters like Detroit and transform the nature of auto manufacturing. The ability of US institutions, including car companies, the government, and labor, to adapt to these changes will determine whether union-friendly states can avoid a new version of the Rust Belt. Electric vehicles are expected to dominate the marketplace in the next couple of decades.

title: Here are some better versions of Bernie Sanders' ideas
summary: The article discusses the shortcomings of America's socialist movement and Bernie Sanders' campaign. The author criticizes the socialists for their obsession with power and factionalism, which led them to focus on attacking Democrats and progressives who weren't part of their faction. The author argues that Bernie and his supporters missed the opportunity to create a real grassroots movement and instead bungled it. However, the problems that fueled the socialist movement, such as expensive healthcare, inequality, high student debt, and climate change, still exist. The author proposes more realistic versions of four of Bernie's ideas: Medicare for All, a wealth tax, student debt cancellation, and the Green New Deal. For universal healthcare, the author suggests using a system like Japan's, which would address the high costs of American healthcare. The author also argues that the focus should be on reducing hidden healthcare costs rather than eliminating out-of-pocket costs. Overall, the author believes that while the socialist movement had its flaws, some of their ideas can be refined and implemented effectively to address the country's major issues.

title: What if Xi Jinping isn't that competent? (repost)
summary: Xi Jinping, the leader of China, is facing criticism for his handling of various issues, including the country's economic slowdown, diplomatic blunders, and the COVID-19 pandemic. Critics argue that Xi's personal objections to certain economic policies and his ideological preference for austerity have hindered efforts to stimulate China's economy. Additionally, Xi's growing paranoia and series of purges of his own officials have caused turmoil within China's leadership. Internationally, Xi's aggressive and bellicose approach has alienated neighboring countries and led to a negative perception of China. Furthermore, China's "zero COVID" policy and reliance on domestically produced vaccines have been met with challenges and have contributed to economic difficulties. Overall, there are concerns about Xi's competence as a leader and the impact of his decisions on China's future. However, given his consolidation of power and the lack of alternatives, it is unlikely that Xi will step down voluntarily.

title: Why do economists get paid more than sociologists?
summary: Economists tend to make higher salaries than sociologists, and there are various reasons for this disparity. One explanation is the difference in supply and demand. Economists have fewer people interested in becoming economists compared to sociologists, which means that universities have to pay economists more to attract them. Additionally, economists have more outside options, such as working in the private sector as consultants or data scientists, which increases their bargaining power and allows them to command higher salaries. Another factor is the higher demand for economics classes from undergraduates, particularly business majors. Universities may be more desperate to hire economists to meet this demand, leading to higher salaries for economists. However, it is challenging to determine the true story behind the salary differential between economists and sociologists, as it requires empirical testing and matching theoretical models to data. Nonetheless, understanding market forces and social factors can shed light on the reasons behind the salary gap.

The author concludes that determining a company's quality and its ability to persist is challenging.

title: My Biggest Issue With “Quality Growth” Stocks
summary: At a recent Quality Growth conference in London, fund managers discussed their investment criteria. The common themes among the managers were a focus on competitive advantage, growth, and the importance of a capable management team. Surprisingly, the frequency of citing returns as a factor was lower than expected. Valuation was mentioned by only half of the managers, with one presenter downplaying its significance. The article also highlights the difficulty of defining and assessing a sustainable competitive advantage. The author then shares a list of hot buttons for identifying quality and growth stocks, obtained from Chat GPT. The list includes factors such as earnings growth, revenue growth, competitive advantage, and valuation. The author acknowledges the challenge of executing a quality growth strategy and plans to explore the topic further in future articles. The article also discusses a presentation by Baillie Gifford, which emphasized the importance of staying the course with growth stocks and focusing on the long term. The presentation highlighted the gains and drawdowns of Baillie Gifford's top 10 winners and emphasized the need to let winners run.

title: Transmedics, a secular med-tech winner?
summary: Transmedics, a medical technology company, has developed the Organ Care System (OCS), a machine that preserves organs for transplantation. The OCS replicates the conditions of the body and perfuses oxygenated blood, creating a better environment for organ preservation. While there is no strong clinical evidence that OCS-preserved organs have better outcomes than those preserved using traditional cold storage, cardiologists tend to prefer OCS-preserved organs. The OCS also broadens the potential pool of organ recipients by allowing transportation of organs to distant locations. Transmedics focuses on liver and heart transplants, which are growing markets with a significant gap between supply and demand. The company operates on a pay-per-use model, offering the OCS to hospitals as part of its National OCS Program. Transmedics faces competition from cold storage methods and other warm perfusion systems, but it enjoys a first-mover advantage and limited competition. Risks to the company include execution and the challenge of building a logistical aviation network. Despite these risks, Transmedics has a strong market position and potential for growth, with a projected enterprise value of $5 billion by 2028.

title: Updating Polya on Style

Another colleague suggests a more cynical amendment, stating that if you have two things to say, it's better to say nothing because nobody wants to hear it.

title: Italy's BTPs
summary: Italian bonds have been outperforming other European bonds, but interest rates across Europe are expected to rise, which could impact Italian bonds. Italy's 30-year BTP yields have reached their highest level since January 2014. The current setup suggests that yields will increase across the curve and risk premiums will rise. The spread between Italian bonds and German Bunds is expected to form a cyclical trend. The article provides yield targets for Italy's 2-year and 10-year bonds, as well as the 5-30 yield curve and the BTP-Bund 10-year spread. The article also includes charts and analysis for each of these metrics. The technical setup indicates that the trend change will be durable, but the driving factors behind the trend change are still uncertain. Overall, the article suggests that the trend in Italian bonds is likely to change in the coming months.

title: China Consumer Borrowings
summary: Chinese consumer sentiment remains weak and cautious, with borrowing patterns indicating mortgage repayment and lower demand for long-term loans. There has been an increase in secondary market real estate interest in some parts of big cities, but smaller cities show a different trend. The decline in secondary market housing prices has a significant impact on consumer spending and savings patterns. Deposit increases typically precede a rise in short-term loan demand. The Catering and Hotel Index has held support, suggesting a potential bounce and future impact on consumer sentiment. Overall, the outlook for Chinese consumer spending is mixed, with signs of recovery but also caution among consumers.

title: A Value Trap, an Ancient Stock Pitch, a Glimpse Into The Past
summary: The author discusses two investment experiences: one with a small company called Four Corners, Inc. and another with Wilh. Wilhelmsen Holding ASA. In the case of Four Corners, the author had invested in the company and was pleased with its performance until it agreed to a transaction that would sell its assets at a discount, benefiting insiders. This highlights the importance of management in small companies and the misalignment of interests between insiders and outside investors. On the other hand, the author reflects on their investment in Wilh. Wilhelmsen Holding ASA, which traded at a significant discount to its asset value. Despite the lack of value-unlocking transactions, the company's underlying assets grew in value, resulting in a good return for shareholders. This emphasizes the importance of analyzing the growth potential of underlying assets rather than solely focusing on the discount to net asset value. The author also shares some interesting historical tidbits about Monarch Cement and reflects on the prevalence of prejudice in the early 20th century. title: "Turbocharged"
summary: Walt Disney's theme park, Disneyland, which opened in 1955, revolutionized the entertainment industry and led to the creation of other successful parks such as Walt Disney World, Tokyo Disney Resort, Disneyland Resort Paris, and Hong Kong Disneyland. However, the Parks & Resorts business faced challenges after the September 11th attacks and experienced a decline in profitability. In 2003, then CEO Michael Eisner predicted a continued reduction in capital expenditures and an increase in free cash flow. This prediction came true, with average annual capital expenditures from 2004 to 2008 decreasing compared to previous years, while segment EBITDA less capital expenditures doubled. This resulted in increased free cash flow for Disney's Parks, Experiences, and Products segment.

Maguire believes that Marlowe is undervalued and presents a good investment opportunity. He highlights the company's strong financial performance, with revenues and EBITDA meeting targets and showing good organic growth. He also mentions the potential for a sale of the TIC business, which could unlock significant value for shareholders. Maguire addresses the bear case, which focuses on the company's adjusted earnings and lack of cash flow. He argues that the adjustments are necessary for integration costs and that the cash flow profile of the business is solid. He also discusses the management incentives and the potential for capital allocation decisions. Overall, Maguire sees Marlowe as a cheap and fundamentally sound investment opportunity.

title: The Leaves Turn Over
summary: The Federal Reserve's rate hike campaign appears to be over, with the probability of further rate hikes diminishing quickly. Critics of direct air capture (DAC) technology raise valid concerns, but The Gregor Letter argues that we should invest in DAC regardless. The US government is making moves to support DAC, including announcing prize money and funding for demonstration projects. However, the missing element in current DAC discourse is the vision of how DAC would look in its optimal state, running on 100% clean energy. Driving an electric vehicle (EV) in any US state now creates less pollution than an internal combustion engine (ICE) car, according to Yale Climate Connections. This assessment is based on the fuel mix in each state's electricity grid. While this analysis only considers the pump-to-wheel accounting, which excludes upstream mining and CO2 emissions, EVs still outperform ICE vehicles in both pump-to-wheel and well-to-wheel accounting. The Gregor Letter has been presenting comprehensive well-to-wheel accountings for years, showing the superiority of EVs over ICE vehicles.

title: Monday Chart
summary: The world's energy system has seen minimal change in the past decade, with natural gas, hydro, and nuclear maintaining a stable global energy share. However, coal and oil have experienced significant declines in market share, with coal losing three percentage points and oil losing one and a half percentage points. Renewables, particularly wind and solar, have seen a significant increase in global energy share, gaining nearly six percentage points. The challenge in decarbonization lies in cleaning up transportation and industrial processes, which require more complex solutions than cleaning up power grids. The stagnation of global nuclear power over the past 20 years is seen as a missed opportunity to further reduce the market share of natural gas. The article emphasizes the need for a comprehensive approach to decarbonization that includes not only wind, solar, and batteries but also electrification of vehicles and the development of nuclear power.

title: Issue #119 - Experiencing the Here & Now of Chinese Tourism in Macau!
summary: Macau is experiencing a surge in tourism during the October Golden Week, with an average of 100,000 daily tourists expected. Despite its small size of 33.3 sq km, Macau is attracting a large number of visitors, easily surpassing its population of 680,000. The Global Tourism Economy Forum (GTEF) in Macau, attended by tourism ministers and leaders from various organizations, is being hailed as the "Davos of Tourism." Macau is investing in night-time attractions and non-gaming entertainment to appeal to a younger demographic. The hotel industry in Macau has seen a significant recovery, with high occupancy rates and increased room rates. The city is also focusing on diversifying its economy and attracting investment in sectors such as health and wellness, MICE, and cultural events. The Hong Kong-Zhuhai-Macau Bridge is playing a crucial role in improving connectivity and boosting tourism in the Greater Bay Area. Macau's casino resorts are investing in residency shows and developing a year-round concert schedule to enhance its nightlife. The city is transforming into a destination with themed resorts, such as The Londoner, The Venetian, and The Parisian, offering a variety of entertainment options.

title: Retail sales ceiling?, CPI commodity components and Chart roundup
summary: Retail sales in China remain weak, with the recovery seen in travel and services rather than consumable goods. The property market also remains subdued despite policy loosening. Monthly retail sales values have been between CNY 3.5 and 4.0 trillion, and it is uncertain whether CNY 4 trillion is a ceiling or if it will be surpassed later in the year. China's policymakers are hoping for a big jump in sales in the last three months of the year. The re-opening boost in sales was mainly due to base effects. The article includes charts showing the inverse relationship between 2023 and 2022 sales for certain months. The categories for firms above a designated size are also discussed.

title: Burning Out with Brad Stulberg
summary: The article discusses the intersection of burnout and parenting, with insights from Brad Stulberg, an expert on peak performance and burnout. Stulberg shares his personal experience with burnout and how he integrates physical exercise and wellbeing practices into his professional life. He emphasizes the importance of creating work-life harmony and defining core values to maintain internal balance. Stulberg also discusses the challenges faced by parents in balancing their responsibilities and feeling like they are never good enough. He suggests that having children can be both anti-burnout medicine and a source of increased strain, depending on the individual. Stulberg advocates for a balanced approach to masculinity that embraces both strength and vulnerability. He also highlights the importance of patience, presence, and vulnerability in parenting. The article concludes with a discussion on the emotional journey of becoming a father and the need for men to be patient with themselves and their evolving connection with their children.

summary: Morningstar Hong Kong & Singapore's YouTube channel features short weekly Stock of the Week videos, primarily focusing on China, Hong Kong, Japan, and Singapore stock picks. summary: The article discusses the flawed Argentina ETF and its holdings, highlighting some alternative ways to gain exposure to the country.
